text: Our country’s food supply is especially important right now. I urge the Administration to support the agriculture industry during these trying times to help avoid a disruption in our food supply chain and make sure Americans have access to food they need. https://t.co/gHAzSHaV71

Wyoming wants to see your business stay. Learn how to apply here: https://t.co/SOJLJfSAp1 https://t.co/YGjig5XYZT

The COVID-19 pandemic has shown how important domestic food security is. I joined a letter urging the Administration to provide assistance to cattle producers to help ensure our country is fed.  https://t.co/ihbQ357DrJ

In Wyoming, we know you have to be willing to invest in technological innovation to create a more sustainable future for coal and our energy industry. This announcement proves that our state is effective in these efforts.
I’m pleased the EPA is taking steps toward granting Wyoming the authority to regulate its own storage of carbon dioxide. https://t.co/HSlY11xstI

I joined a letter asking Health and Human Services Secretary Azar to prioritize rural hospitals in implementing the CARES Act, which provides emergency financial assistance to support health providers. https://t.co/sNi7lIcvi0
Rural hospitals are critical in our efforts to defeat the coronavirus, but face many challenges. We ask the administration to act swiftly to sustain them.

Many scammers are taking advantage of fears surrounding COVID-19. It's important to remain vigilant. If something seems too good to be true, it often is. Always fact check information & don’t click links from sources you don’t know. Report scam attempts: https://t.co/quaIEjQVxo

Today is Census Day! A few minutes of your time will help our country. I’m encouraging folks in Wyoming to complete the census online, over the phone or by mail. Everyone’s response is important. Go to https://t.co/CIFd8frAIS for more information. https://t.co/l29VSX8Yit

Help is on the way, America! The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act is here to provide financial assistance all across the country. With more opportunities available, here are a few highlights for your family, business, health and more. https://t.co/2GtDc2mvKj

He was a man of principle who scrutinized legislation & worked to make government better for the people. He provided great advice and wisdom to me. He did a tremendous job serving his state and his nation during his time in the House and Senate. We could use more people like him.

Tom Coburn was one of the best senators I ever had the pleasure to serve with. Diana and I send our thoughts and prayers to his wife, Carolyn, and their family. As a doctor and as a public servant, he dedicated his life to helping folks.

During this time of crisis, President @realDonaldTrump, Vice President @Mike_Pence and all the members of the Admin’s #coronavirus response team have made a real difference to the nation and Wyoming with their leadership and daily briefings. Thank you!

I joined a group of senators in urging the Trump Admin to consider using trade policy to reduce economic strains on our country. By doing this, we can create new opportunities for American exports to restore confidence in our economy. https://t.co/Xtz3zzsK6V

Employees are losing their jobs and businesses are having to shut down, through no fault of their own. They need our help. I urge the House to quickly pass this legislation so folks can get the relief they need.
After a lot of tense discussions, I’m pleased the Senate finally passed this third bipartisan relief package to help individuals, small businesses and the economy. https://t.co/N15OQ6JAtm

In this time of crisis and economic uncertainty, I’m disappointed the @EPA did not stand up for small oil refineries in Wyoming. The decision not to appeal hurts small refineries & puts workers' jobs at risk & harms the communities that rely on them. https://t.co/GPT0Q3QwXr

Wyoming is being awarded over $340,000 from the Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Funding for several health centers. This will help our hardworking health professionals keep our communities safe. We’re still working to get more done. https://t.co/ScaRAlOyu0
Many workers have been laid off and have lost their paychecks. We need to work together to pass this bill now! https://t.co/ZIcbWoUuGR

Why isn’t there more concern for the employees out of work? We have a bill to provide enormous financial assistance, but my colleagues across the aisle are holding it up in order to forward their own agenda on unrelated issues. Rome is burning and Congress is fiddling! https://t.co/mCxfHhysnT
Agriculture is one of Wyoming’s top industries. With over 90% of operations being family-run, it brings in more than a billion dollars to our state every year.

Remember to thank your farmers and ranchers who work tirelessly during these difficult times to provide us with food. These important jobs, and rigorous lifestyles, help keep our country healthy and fed. #thankafarmer https://t.co/IuYNhnoBbV
The Senate is still working on a “phase 3” economic relief package to help individuals and small businesses. I am working with my colleagues and hoping we can get it passed quickly.

I’ve put together some helpful links to resources and information for folks in Wyoming – from small businesses, to employment, to health care resources – on the homepage of my website. https://t.co/XpSoJS5BnF
In these uncertain and quickly changing times, there are a lot of unanswered questions. I know there is an overwhelming amount of information about COVID-19 right now.

The Senate is working on a third package in response to COVID-19 that I hope will help small businesses make payments to employees & the things they need to maintain their business, like rent, electricity and heating. I encourage small business owners to hold on, help is coming.
We are in difficult, unprecedented times. For many small businesses, it is disastrous. https://t.co/BoveybGbYx https://t.co/mBdlyQ5Dr8
The best way to stay up to date is to go to https://t.co/MGcliKIOMC. Read more about these false claims here: https://t.co/YA4huPWCED

The Stafford Act only allows for the federal government to provide state and local governments with disaster relief and emergency assistance. President Trump invoked the Stafford Act when he declared a national emergency in response to COVID-19.
Social media posts, text messages and voicemails have been circulating claiming that the president will invoke the Stafford Act to order a mandatory two-week quarantine.

HOAX ALERT: If you’ve been misled and panicked by rumors about military action and the Stafford Act, just google Stafford Act to see that it is a huge hoax. With new updates about COVID-19 coming every day, it’s important to stay alert for misleading information.

Diana and I are sending our gratitude to truck drivers. Next time you see a trucker, thank her or him.

Truckers are an important link keeping hospitals, grocery stores and everything in between supplied in spite of the virus. They are moms and dads, husbands and wives. They are some of the hardest working, patriotic people in the country moving virtually all of the goods.

There are a lot of folks across the country working hard to ensure we have the essential resources or services we need during this challenging time. Truck drivers are one of them and they don’t get much attention. When they do, it’s often underappreciated.

As the husband of a colorectal cancer survivor, I know firsthand how early detection and treatment is essential. Look out for symptoms, learn your family history and get screened - it could save your life.

Every March, I’m proud to support National Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month. Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths, so it is critical to get screened. https://t.co/HgP2X753MZ
RT @wysbdc: Our response to #coronavirus and resources for Wyoming small businesses dealing with the crisis.

Happy birthday, @GirlScouts! I appreciate what the Girl Scouts organization has done over the past 108 years to help prepare girls across Wyoming and the country for bright futures.

Americans should have access to affordable, high-quality health care, which cannot be done if patients can’t afford their prescriptions. I’m proud to work on a bill that focuses on lowering prescription drug costs while not hindering the development of new drugs. https://t.co/qcVbq52A8Z

Today is 307 day (March 7) for Wyoming! The one and only 307 area code is symbolic of our state – which is said to be one small town with long roads. If you are a proud 307 resident, celebrate and post one of your favorite photos of our Cowboy State! https://t.co/UpQOc157lu

It’s encouraging to hear reports that the Trump administration will appeal a court decision that would hurt small refineries in Wyoming and across the country. If the decision were to stand, thousands of jobs would be at risk. https://t.co/VwXDfDiBRh

Great Smoky Mountains National Park, North Carolina and Tennessee: Home to about 1,500 bears and more than 800 miles of hiking trails. This park is the most visited in the country! 

Great Smoky Mountains backlog: $235,895,973 https://t.co/02wxubhsts

Glacier National Park, Montana: This park contains a peak where its summer melt supplies water to three separate oceans. The park also includes a 50-mile scenic drive.  

Glacier National Park’s backlog: $131,189,894 https://t.co/NRkuKfoPSM

Mammoth Cave National Park, Kentucky: Believed to be first explored some 5,000 years ago, the caves are the longest known cave system in the world with 400 miles surveyed. 

Mammoth Cave’s backlog: $92,411,481 https://t.co/HEW07lkxLI

Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona: Created around the largest canyon in North America, so big it can create its own weather; this park holds spectacular views and an estimated 1,000 hidden caves. 

Grand Canyon’s backlog: $313,866,913 https://t.co/wPhN5sGLLP

Yosemite National Park, California: Filled with many waterfalls and massive granite rock features, it is also home to one of the tallest waterfalls in the world. 

Yosemite’s backlog: $645,657,601 https://t.co/UimZLpsd62

Here is a thread of some parks at risk. 

Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, Idaho and Montana: The first national park, home to hundreds wildlife species and more than 10,000 hydrothermal features.
 
Yellowstone's backlog:  $585,548,997 https://t.co/2gbYdvDnrT

I introduced the REAL Act to address this nearly $12 billion backlog while not adding to our national debt. By raising visa fees & a minimal park fee increase, we can #repairourparks. In Wyoming, about 7,000 jobs would come out of addressing our backlog, according to the NPS.

Our national parks are a reflection of our country. With more than 300 million visitors every year and limited resources, a backlog of maintenance work has been created, spanning from road repairs to preserving trails and campgrounds.

I enjoy hearing the updates from the young Scouts and am so proud of them. This year was especially memorable because I received a copy of the Boy Scout Handbook signed by President George H.W. Bush. https://t.co/NafsB7BIRa

Every year, according to the National Charter of the Boy Scouts of America, the Scouts must submit a report to Congress about its recent programs, initiatives and major accomplishments. And every year, this event is one of the most spectacular events I get to attend. https://t.co/AHKrFlzGmF

During our delegation’s Wyoming Wednesday events, I get the chance to meet people from all over our state who travel to D.C. I introduced two amendments to the American Energy Innovation Act that would help highlight the importance of rare earth elements and the role Wyoming can play in mining and producing them. https://t.co/fLelHCcjkr
Rare earth elements are important to our country’s energy independence and are crucial in meeting our technological needs – from smart phones and televisions to wind turbines and jet fighter engines.

Glad @RealDonaldTrump wants our National Parks properly maintained for generations to come — I do too. That’s why my bill would address the nearly $12 billion maintenance backlog w/ some help from our foreign visitors without adding to our national debt. https://t.co/shReAinlRb https://t.co/DoQyyKDa8z

The CFPB is a dangerously unaccountable agency - its lavish spending on employee salaries is just one example. I introduced a bill that would set salaries according to the government’s standard pay scale & bring some much-needed oversight and transparency. https://t.co/DBud40HZth
Yellowstone is one of my favorite places to visit in the state. https://t.co/0X3i9u9es2

Happy birthday, Yellowstone! Our country’s first national park was founded on this day in 1872. It is home to about 67 species of mammals, 285 species of birds and more than 500 active geysers. @YellowstoneNPS https://t.co/2FHdltVlVL

Less than three years ago, the U.S. suspended all Brazilian beef imports because of public health concerns. I’m concerned that the recent decision to lift this ban could lead to more issues and that these beef imports won’t be properly monitored. https://t.co/WHXW4fELKT

In Wyoming alone, it’s been exciting to watch the technical programs grow, from the Wind River Job Corps, to our community colleges, to Climb Wyoming and the Wyoming Contractors Association Regional Training Center.

One of the recent laws I am most proud of is the Strengthening Career and Technical Education Act, which made improvements to career and technical education programs for those who want to work with their hands in high-wage, high-demand jobs.

I am proud to cosponsor the resolution declaring February as Career and Technical Education month. It's important that we continue to recognize all the programs working to prepare folks for important careers in high demand. https://t.co/3JvcHG6iGV

Diana and I were customers of Sheridan Iron Works shortly after we were married. It was neat to come back to visit the renovated workshop - which built submarine parts during WWII. In 2018, Wyoming produced about $270 million exports to Canada and Mexico. For many industries like agriculture, machinery and minerals, this deal would help create and maintain quality jobs in the state while fostering new innovation and fairer trade across the board.

I was proud to join my colleagues on the Senate Finance Committee today to vote in support of the United States, Mexico and Canada Agreement, bringing the deal one step closer to final approval. https://t.co/DLR3iebxYT
